title: 110_s3540
content: The "Drug Free Families Act of 2008" may be cited as the short title for the Act. It establishes a drug testing program for applicants and recipients of assistance under state TANF programs. The "Drug Free Families Act of 2008" establishes a drug testing program for applicants and recipients of assistance under state TANF programs, requiring states to operate a program to test all applicants for illegal drug use and deny assistance to those who test positive or are convicted of drug-related crimes. The "Drug Free Families Act of 2008" mandates drug testing for applicants and recipients of state TANF assistance, including random or scheduled testing for illegal drug use after initial screening. Individuals found to have used illegal drugs or convicted of drug-related offenses may be denied assistance. The "Drug Free Families Act of 2008" requires drug testing for TANF applicants and recipients, denying assistance to those not tested for illegal drug use or convicted of drug-related offenses. The "Drug Free Families Act of 2008" mandates drug testing for TANF applicants and recipients. Assistance will be denied to individuals who test positive for illegal drug use or are convicted of drug-related crimes. Individuals receiving assistance under the State program must complete a drug rehabilitation or treatment program and test negative for illegal drug use within a 6-month period. The State may continue assistance for those not convicted of a felony drug-related crime, but may conduct random drug tests thereafter. The State may deny assistance to individuals who fail to meet program requirements, with a 2-year waiting period for reapplication. Individuals denied assistance three times for drug-related reasons face permanent denial of benefits. The State may deny assistance to individuals who fail to meet program requirements, with a 2-year waiting period for reapplication. Individuals denied assistance three times for drug-related reasons face permanent denial of benefits. The Secretary may not waive the provisions of this paragraph under section 1115. Definitions for illegal drug and drug rehabilitation or treatment are provided. The term 'drug rehabilitation or treatment program' refers to a program approved by the State that complies with all relevant laws and regulations to help rehabilitate drug users. 'Drug-related crime' is defined as any crime involving illegal drugs. The amendments made by this section will take effect on the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter after a specified date. The amendments made by this Act require State plans to meet additional requirements by the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter after the close of the 1st regular session of the State legislature following the enactment date. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is considered a separate regular session of the State legislature.
